issue.title: Add Helm bug about takeOwnership and custom resources

repository.name: fleet
repository.description: Deploy workloads from Git to large fleets of Kubernetes clusters

body: I managed to reproduce this. The necessary labels required to track the resource as managed by Helm are not applied.
I'll try to get  PR raised for this

@banjoh Please note that I have created a [pull request that would enable to fix this](https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/13411), but it was considered a feature. I have created this issue to adapt the pull request and make it a bug fix only.

So, instead of introducing a new CLI parameter that could have been used in conjunction with `--take-ownerhip`, but also without it, I plan to transparently enable the three way merge of CRs only if `--take-ownership` is used.
@p-se oh, I hadn't realised there was an existing PR for this. I'll review it instead. Thanks for the work put in.
@p-se do you mind updating the PR description so this issue is attributed to the PR?

issue.title: Fix --take-ownership for custom resources - closes #30622

labels.name: size/L
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

issue.body:
If a resource exists in the cluster and is to be adopted by helm install --take-ownership, it is left unchanged while helm reports the installation to have succeeded.

This is due to CRs and CRDs being merged without three-way-merge, which results in an empty patch.

By using a three-way-merge transparently when --take-ownership is used, helm behaves as expected without breaking previous behavior.

Fixes #30622

<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
1. Make sure to read the Contributing Guide before submitting your PR: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
2. If this PR closes another issue, add 'closes #<issue number>' somewhere in the PR summary. GitHub will automatically close that issue when this PR gets merged. Alternatively, adding 'refs #<issue number>' will not close the issue, but help provide the reviewer more context.-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

**If applicable**:
- [ ] this PR contains user facing changes (the `docs needed` label should be applied if so)
  --take-ownership does not appear to be documented at all, so perhaps yes from that perspective, but no from the perspective of this PR.
- [x] this PR contains unit tests
- [ ] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility
  The changes in this PR are meant to not change any existing behavior, except for how helm behaves when called with `--take-ownership`.

body:
> [@p-se](https://github.com/p-se) do you mind updating the PR description so this issue is attributed to the PR?

Not at all.

Please don't review my previous PR as it has been considered a feature request that is not going to be merged. The PR I have created today is solely for the purpose of making `--take-ownership` work as expected and does not change anything else. I would appreciate a review on that one.

issue.title: [SURE-8849] fleet incorrectly reports pre-existing resources as missing when setting helm.takeOwnership: true

repository.name: fleet
repository.description: Deploy workloads from Git to large fleets of Kubernetes clusters

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

When settings `helm.takeOwernship: true` , the chart deployment will add the standard helm labels and annotations to an existing object.  E.g.:

```yaml
apiVersion: ceph.rook.io/v1
kind: CephFilesystem
metadata:
  annotations:
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: rook-ceph-conf
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: rook-ceph
    ...
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
```

However, `fleet-agent` will complain about missing resources:

```
time="2024-02-07T23:16:25Z" level=error msg="bundle kueyen-only-kueyen-fleet-rook-ceph-conf: cephfilesystem.ceph.rook.io rook-ceph/obs-env missing"
```

As will the `bundle` and `bundleDeployment` resources:

```
NAME                                      DEPLOYED   MONITORED   STATUS
kueyen-only-kueyen-fleet-rook-ceph-conf   True       True        cephfilesystem.ceph.rook.io rook-ceph/obs-env missing
```
```
NAME                                      BUNDLEDEPLOYMENTS-READY   STATUS
kueyen-only-kueyen-fleet-rook-ceph-conf   0/1                       Modified(1) [Cluster fleet-default/kueyen]; cephfilesystem.ceph.rook.io rook-ceph/obs-env missing; cephnfs.ceph.rook.io rook-ceph/obs-env missing; cephobjectstore.ceph.rook.io rook-ceph/lfa missing
```



### Expected Behavior

I expect that "fleet" takes ownership of existing resources and does not report them as missing (when they exists!).

The resource is reported as missing because the pre-existing resources do not have the `objectset.rio.cattle.io/hash` label and `objectset.rio.cattle.io/id` annotation set. E.g.:

```yaml 
    annotations:
      objectset.rio.cattle.io/id: default-kueyen-only-kueyen-fleet-rook-ceph-conf
      ...
    labels:
      app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
      objectset.rio.cattle.io/hash: 563cb3553e5fba84eee5ba3054b9b537c653465a
     ...
```
Manually copying the value of `objectset.rio.cattle.io/hash` from another resource resolves the "missing" resource warning.


### Steps To Reproduce

1. Manually create a resource
2. Create a fleet bundle with `helm.takeOwnership: true` with a duplicate of that resource
3. Observe warnings on the `bundle`, `bundleDeployment` resources and in the `fleet-agent` logs.

### Environment

```markdown
- Architecture: x86-64
- Fleet Version: 0.9.0 (rancher 2.8.1)
- Cluster:
  - Provider: RKE1
  - Kubernetes Version: v1.25.9
```


### Logs

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_
